data.text:
ONLY CONNECT FESTIVAL OF SOUND 2020

Häxan with music by Mauro Lanza and Olivier Pasquet

Changes: Watch onlyconnect.no for the digital festival Only Connect 2020 (From a Safe Distance) 23 - 25 April.

Watch the silent horror documentary Häxan with a soundtrack determined by algorithms.

THURSDAY 23 APRIL

21:00 Tøyen kirke

Buy ticket: concert ticket / festival pass

FESTIVAL PROGRAMME

Composers Mauro Lanza and Olivier Pasquet have created a new soundtrack for the Danish/Swedish silent film Häxan (1922) by Benjamin Christensen. The film points to how misconceptions about mental disorders may have led to which burning.

Häxan was made as a documentary, but contains dramatic elements known from horror films. It shows examples of superstitions and practices of witchcraft, magic and torture. Christensen compares the women who were accused of witchcraft in the Middle Ages with women who had mental disorders in the early 1900s, and draws parallels between the Inquisition and the psychiatric treatment of the "hysterical women".

Lanza and Pasquet’s soundtrack is algorithmically controlled, with music composed by a large collection of sounds. The music is sometimes concrete and sometimes in sync with the image, while other times it slides into the abstract. The basis of the composition is an algorithm that selects and processes a huge audio material of several thousand sounds. This sound material is composed of electronic sounds, samples of instruments and gothic metal, and more.

The work was originally a commission for Ircam and the Louvre Museum.

Häxan was the most expensive Scandinavian silent film ever made in its time, costing almost 2 million Swedish kroner. The film became illegal in the United States and much of it was censored in other countries because of what was considered graphic depictions of torture, nudity and sexual perversion. Director Christensen himself plays the devil in the film.

Italian composer Mauro Lanza (1975) studied piano in Venice and computer music at Ircam. Tingedwith irony, his compositions attempt to intimately merge classical instruments with other less conventional sound sources. He enjoys the clarity and the inhuman character of formalized processes, working extensively with computer algorithms. His music is published by Ricordi Milano. In 2014 he was awarded by Italy’s National Association of Music Critics with the Franco Abbiati Prize.

Olivier Pasquet (b. 1974) is a composer, visual artist and music producer. He has been working with a variety of artists at Ircam and other places, such as Florian Hecker, Georges Aperghis and Pierre Boulez. His work is based on the writing of audio visual compositions and synesthesia. His generative pieces, both minimalistic and maximalistic, are contextualized within a rationalist theory-fiction universe. This world can be explored both by singular pieces and an overall artistic path. The formal and plastic value gives it strong links with architecture, geometry and algorithmic design.
